text:
THE PRINCE ALBERT TIMES
AND SASKATCHEWAN REVIEW.

PRINCE ALBERT, SASK., FRIDAY, MAY 28, 1884.

$2.50 A YEAR.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by "Povemter."
Fishing, is all the rage just now.

Lady Glamorgan holds the record.
Hunter's old cove, from Algoma.

List of Sportsmen be Held Under the Auspices of the Prince Albert Chess Club on the 26th of May:
Running high jump.
Running long jump.
Running low jump.
Jumping high jump.
Running trench.
Walking with stick.
Pulling the stake.
Putting heavy stone, 21 lbs.
Horse race, 300 yards.
Throwing base ball.
Spinning discus.
Handball race.
Run and treadle race.
Two hundred yards race.
Three hundred yards race.
Four hundred yards race.
Six-hundred yards race.
Goose race.
Goos and dog race.
Goos and cat race.
Sliding race.
Race between cart and horse.
Nine hundred yards race.
Ten too hundre yards race.
Thriving basball race.
Trailing race.
Jumping race.
Base race, 100 yards, competitors to furnish their own horse.
Two hundred yards race.
Rodeo under ten yards, 100 yards.
Race by oxen.
Race by horses.
Race by carts.
Race by donkeys.

A list of sportsmen will be held for Winnipeg next week:

Mr. Thomas Howe and brother leave for Princess Plains the beginning of next month.

Freighters arrive from Trout Lake; well paid. Mr. Campbell, Edmonton.

Mr. Peter Hughes has purchased the Tippin House, and intends to use it as a residence.

Mr. J. A. Nielson and two brothers and Mr. Morrison arrived on Monday from Grey.

Mr. H. McLachlin, son of Mr. J. O. McLachlin, will leave for Trout Lake next week.

Mr. Wm. Reid, D. L. S. & Co. has arrived with a staff goods for the opening of our new store in this district.

PROVINCIAL RIGHTS

Sir John A. Macdonald is beyond all question a very clever and astute politician, with the rare genius of statesman that makes any other man by the exception of Count von Bismarck, Chancellor of the German Empire. Fortunately for him however, he possesses certain definite constitutional rights not enjoyed by the Germans, who however evince a determination to have them at no distant date, prevent our being at the mercy of our own government without the aid of the Canadian Parliament. We may soon be deprived of the Dominion together on the present basis of the British North American Act, which has been so long in the making, and which, we believe, will be abandoned in its entirety and important changes have taken place, notably the growth of new and powerful provinces, with their own rights and privileges, and the time is not far off when the question of the future of the Dominion will be decided.

OUR EMIGRANTS

Land monopoly and a surplus population are two vexed questions in the old country, the former having been brought to a head in recent years by the discovery of gold in California. Mr. George, or as they call him "the San Francisco Prophet," can be wondered that so much land is left unsold in the hands of speculators, who run away from the fact that there is a vast amount of land lying idle, and that the people who have been given the land that they have supplied armed men in time of war, which condition has been quickly satisfied on the suffering taxpayer, the remaining surplus going to the benefit of those who have fallen into the hands of capitalists, where it lies unbroken, until, to enable these few monopolists to secure profits, the land must be sold at a high price. In Scotland, there is a great deal of land lying idle, and the question is, how shall the interests of the North West Territories be looked after? With regard to our settlers, each province has a means of making itself heard through its Local Legislature and its representatives in the Dominion Parliament, but the rapid increase of the population, due to the influx of our own territory, entitles us to the management of our territorial interests and a strong voice in the affairs of the Dominion is a matter of vital importance. It must be remembered that the rapidly increasing number of electoral divisions will bring about shortly the natural death of the weak, and the North West Canada, whose partial powers are controlled by Government officials, and the birth of a Legislative Assembly, which would at least express the voice of the people, but it is more likely feared that the situation as it is, is doomed for long enough to disappoiment. It seems only too probable that just as the electoral districts over the whole of the Territory have been drawn up, so, too, will they fail to become a Legislative House, the territories will be subdivided into provinces, each of which will have to work its way up again.

PUBLIC NOTICE

All persons are hereby required to take notice that the execution of the Indian lands without authority from the Minister of Agriculture, Agent of Dominion Lands or the District Agent in public or private sale, or any person acting under authority liable to be prosecuted by the Minister of the Interior. Each settler on a homestead quarter section must make an application to the Local Agent of Dominion Lands, and must pay a fee of twenty-five cents, and must be exceeding twenty acres in extent, at per acre.

Any person other than a homestead settler who wishes to purchase land must make application thereto to the Minister of Agriculture, Agent of Dominion Lands, who will deal with such applications. Persons who have already cut timber without authority will be prosecuted by the Crown Timber Agent at his discretion. Any person who does not otherwise the said timber will be considered under the provisions of the Act.

D. W. GAGNON,
Crown Timber Agent.

FURNITURE

Just arrived, in addition to our former large stock we have received some Fancy Parlor and Bedroom Sets. Give us a call and see our Sideboards, Bureaus, Bedsteads, Couches, Sofas, Chairs of nearly all Descriptions, Cradles & Cribs for the Babies Rocking Chairs for the Ladies Mattresses Single & Double to suit Customers.

C. & G. E. CARTER,
KNOX & BARKER,
CARPENTERS, ETC.

OFFICE AND WORKSHOP

Near Presbyterian Church.

W. J. CARTER,
Builder and Contractor.

All Orders Promptly Attended to.
Plans and estimates furnished when required.
Planning and Matching done to order, next to H. B. C. Great Mill.

Roadside - Near Presbyterian Church.
TERRITORIAL NEWS.

FORT MCLEOD.

From the Herald, May 3.

The river is beginning to rise, and Mr. Hill has been doing some work with his boat, and will soon be ready to start.

REGINA.

From the Leader, May 3.

Mr. Charles Ross, who owns farms in the Qu'Appelle Valley, has acquired a new horse, which he calls "Honest and a thoroughbred."

MOOSE JAW.

From the Leader, May 3.

A group of men are at work excavating a grave near the old Fort. They believe they have found the remains of a man who died several years ago. They have not yet identified him.

PRINCE ALBERT.

From the Leader, May 3.

The Royal Route.

Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapolis & Omaha, and Chicago & Northwestern Railroad.

Passengers of the Royal Route have all the comforts of Modern Railway Travel. First Class Cabins, spacious sleeping accommodations, and excellent food. For Expressmen who are not familiar with the route, there is a special rate for passengers between Minneapolis and Chicago, and Chicago and Kansas City.

ROYAL ROUTE.

J. H. HIGHLAND, Genl. Traffic Manager.

First Carts—First Arrival from Troy.

O. E. HUGHES & CO.

First Carts—First Arrival from Troy.

JAMES SINCLAIR.

Merchant Tailor, and Dealer in GENTS' FURNISHINGS.

HATS

CAPS

SPRING GOODS!

WM. R. BELL.

DRY LUMBER.

MOORE & MACDOWALL

Wish to inform the Public that they have on hand and for sale a Half Million Feet of Dry Lumber, consisting of Matched, Dressed and Undressed.

Dressed Flooring, $48
Undressed do., 42
Dressed Siding, 48
Undressed do., 42
Sheeting, 30
Common Lumber, 35
Dimension do., 40

Lathe, 75 cts. per bundle.
Shingles, $6.50 per M.

We are prepared to Contract for Buildings as cheaply as any firm in Town.

Builders paying Cash or giving good security for large orders, will have a reduction made.

GENERAL MERCHANTS.

NOTICE.

Notice is hereby given that all my accounts are now closed, and all papers indebted to me are expected to settle the same promptly; if not paid, will be added to my next bill.

N.B.: This order after this date I will keep to book accounts. Terms strictly cash.

W.M. GORDON.

Patents.

Watches, Clocks, Jewellery, Stationery.

R.B. WAY,

Post Office, Prince Albert, S.W.L.
